artefacts.name: Oldowan Tools
artefacts.description: Early stone tools used by Homo habilis and Homo erectus. These tools were made by chipping flakes off a larger stone, and they were used for a variety of tasks, such as cutting, scraping, and piercing. The production of Oldowan tools required basic flint-knapping skills.

artefacts.name: Olorgesailie Prehistoric Site
artefacts.description: Excavations at Olorgesailie have revealed Acheulean tools, including handaxes and cleavers. These tools were skilfully crafted using stone knapping techniques and were utilised for various purposes such as butchering, woodworking, and hunting.

artefacts.name: Sterkfontein and Swartkrans Caves
artefacts.description: Excavations at these caves have uncovered early human artifacts, including stone tools. The production of these tools required considerable expertise in selecting suitable rocks and shaping them using precise flint-knapping techniques. They were used for tasks such as cutting, scraping, and hunting.

artefacts.name: Wonderwerk Cave
artefacts.description: Excavations at Wonderwerk Cave have revealed stone tools, hearths, and animal remains. The tools found at the site were carefully crafted using stone knapping techniques and were utilised for various tasks, including cutting, scraping, and butchering. The construction of hearths demonstrates early human control of fire.

artefacts.name: Pebble tools
artefacts.description: These tools were made by carefully selecting suitable pebbles and shaping them through percussion and flaking techniques. They were likely used for various tasks such as cutting, pounding, and scraping.

artefacts.name: Hand axes
artefacts.locationName: Tunisia, Algeria, Morocco, and the Sahara region
artefacts.description: These hand axes were meticulously crafted using advanced stone knapping techniques, involving the removal of flakes to shape the tools into a symmetrical form. They were versatile tools used for cutting, chopping, and even as weapons.

artefacts.name: Tanged points
artefacts.description: These specialised tools were created by carefully shaping flakes and flake blades into a distinct tanged point form. They were likely used for hunting, spearing, and other tasks that required a sharp and robust point.

artefacts.name: Large bifacial hand axes
artefacts.description: These substantial bifacial hand axes were expertly crafted using knapping techniques to shape both sides, resulting in a symmetrical design. They were likely versatile tools used for cutting, chopping, and shaping various materials.

artefacts.name: Blombos Cave Engravings
artefacts.description: These intricate engravings, created by incising patterns into various surfaces, demonstrate the artistic abilities of the Middle Stone Age inhabitants. The engravings often depict symbols, animals, or abstract designs.

artefacts.name: Howiesons Poort Stone Tools
artefacts.description: These stone tools exhibit a high degree of craftsmanship and include various types such as points, scrapers, and blades. They were likely used for hunting, cutting, and other daily activities.

artefacts.name: Bone Harpoons
artefacts.description: These harpoons were crafted from bone, typically mammal or fish bone, and feature barbed points that aided in hunting aquatic or land-based animals. They demonstrate the skillful use of bone as a versatile material.

artefacts.name: Ochre Processing Tools
artefacts.description: These tools were used to extract and process ochre, a naturally occurring pigment used for various purposes such as body adornment, cave paintings, and symbolic markings. They show evidence of early human creativity and cultural practices.

artefacts.name: Shell Beads
artefacts.description: These beads, made from various shell species, were likely used for personal adornment and served as a form of currency or social signaling. Their production required meticulous craftsmanship and symbolized the aesthetic and symbolic values of the Middle Stone Age communities.

artefacts.name: Backed Microliths
artefacts.description: These small stone tools were carefully crafted with precise flint-knapping techniques. They feature a distinct backing on one side, which facilitated hafting onto other materials, such as wood or bone, to create composite tools. Backed microliths were likely used as arrowheads, spear tips, or cutting implements.

artefacts.name: Levallois Points
artefacts.description: These distinctive stone tools were manufactured using the Levallois technique, a sophisticated method that involved carefully preparing a core to produce flakes of predetermined shapes and sizes. Levallois points were versatile tools used for cutting, scraping, and hunting.

artefacts.name: Engraved Ostrich Eggshell Fragments
artefacts.description: These fragments exhibit intricate engravings created on the surface of ostrich eggshells. The engravings may depict symbolic or representational patterns and demonstrate the artistic skills and cultural expressions of the Middle Stone Age communities.

artefacts.name: Bone Tools
artefacts.description: These tools were crafted from various animal bones and served a variety of purposes, such as leatherworking, weaving, or hafting other stone or organic materials. They demonstrate the resourcefulness and adaptability of the Middle Stone Age communities.

artefacts.name: Shellfish Middens and Fishing Gear
artefacts.description: These archaeological remains consist of discarded shellfish shells accumulated over time by prehistoric communities. The presence of fishing gear suggests the development of specialized tools and techniques for harvesting marine resources, indicating a sophisticated understanding of the environment and the exploitation of coastal resources.

artefacts.name: Bone Spearheads
artefacts.locationName: Twin Rivers and Klasies River Caves
artefacts.description: These finely crafted spearheads were fashioned from animal bones, exhibiting skilled craftsmanship and functional design. Bone spearheads were effective hunting weapons, used by prehistoric communities to bring down large game and secure food resources.

artefacts.name: Tassili n'Ajjer Rock Art
artefacts.description: The rock art of Tassili n'Ajjer depicts various scenes, including human figures, animals, and geometric patterns. Created by prehistoric communities using natural pigments, these paintings offer glimpses into the artistic expressions, cultural practices, and beliefs of ancient societies.

artefacts.name: Nabta Playa Megaliths
artefacts.description: These megalithic structures, arranged in complex patterns, reflect the engineering skills and astronomical knowledge of the Late Stone Age communities. They may have served as ceremonial or ritual sites, potentially related to the observation of celestial events.

artefacts.name: Stone Circles of Senegambia
artefacts.description: These enigmatic stone formations consist of upright standing stones arranged in circular or elliptical patterns. The purpose and significance of these stone circles are still subjects of archaeological inquiry, offering insights into the religious, social, or cultural practices of the Late Stone Age communities.

artefacts.name: Cattle Engravings and Rock Paintings
artefacts.description: These engravings and paintings depict cattle, often portrayed in elaborate scenes or with symbolic elements. They reflect the cultural significance of cattle as a vital resource, an indicator of wealth, and a central element of social and ritual practices during the Late Stone Age.

artefacts.name: Nok Terracotta Sculptures
artefacts.description: These exquisite sculptures represent human figures with distinctive facial features and intricate details. Created by the Nok civilization, these sculptures highlight the artistic and technical skills of Late Stone Age societies in working with clay. They offer insights into the cultural and artistic traditions of the time.

artefacts.name: Painted Cave Rock Art
artefacts.description: These ancient rock paintings depict various subjects, including animals, humans, and abstract symbols. Created using natural pigments, these artworks provide insights into the spiritual beliefs, cultural practices, and artistic expressions of the Late Stone Age communities.

artefacts.name: Gobero Pottery
artefacts.description: The pottery from Gobero represents the ceramic traditions of Late Stone Age communities in the region. These vessels, crafted using various techniques and decorated with intricate patterns or motifs, served practical and symbolic purposes. The pottery provides insights into the cultural and technological advancements of the time.

artefacts.name: Great Zimbabwe Ruins
artefacts.description: Great Zimbabwe was the capital of a medieval kingdom and an important trading center in the region. The ruins feature impressive stone walls, structures, and architectural elements, showcasing the advanced engineering and craftsmanship of the Late Stone Age civilization.

artefacts.name: Djenne-Djenno Terracotta Figures
artefacts.description: These finely crafted terracotta figurines showcase the artistic skills of the Late Stone Age civilization in the region. The figures depict human and animal subjects, providing insights into the cultural and religious practices of the ancient societies.

artefacts.name: Tichitt Walata Archaeological Sites
artefacts.description: The Tichitt and Walata sites bear evidence of ancient settlements, showcasing the architectural and technological achievements of the Late Stone Age civilization. These sites may have served as centers of trade, culture, and social interaction during their occupation.

artefacts.name: Garamantes Petroglyphs
artefacts.description: These rock engravings depict various scenes, including human figures, animals, and geometric patterns, providing insights into the cultural beliefs and practices of the Late Stone Age communities in the region.

artefacts.name: Tenerian Rock Art
artefacts.description: The Tenerian rock art consists of paintings and engravings depicting various subjects, including animals, human figures, and symbols. These artworks provide valuable insights into the daily life, spiritual beliefs, and artistic expressions of the ancient societies.

artefacts.name: Tsodilo Rock Art
artefacts.description: The paintings depict various subjects, including wildlife, humans, and ritual scenes, offering valuable insights into the spiritual and cultural practices of ancient societies.

artefacts.name: Elmenteitan Pottery
artefacts.description: Elmenteitan pottery is known for its unique shapes and decorations, serving both functional and symbolic purposes. The pottery artifacts provide valuable insights into the artistic and technological advancements of the Late Stone Age civilization.

artefacts.name: Gerzeh Pottery
artefacts.description: Gerzeh pottery exhibits sophisticated designs and craftsmanship, reflecting the cultural and technological achievements of the Late Stone Age communities in the region. The pottery served utilitarian and ceremonial purposes, and the artifacts are valuable for understanding the social and economic life of ancient Egypt.

artefacts.name: Songo Mnara Ruins
artefacts.description: Songo Mnara was a thriving trading port during the Late Stone Age, connecting East Africa to other parts of the world. The ruins include architectural remains, such as houses and mosques, providing insights into the urban and maritime history of the region.

artefacts.name: Polished Stone Axes
artefacts.description: The polished stone axes were essential tools for the Late Stone Age communities, serving various purposes such as agriculture, hunting, and woodworking. These artifacts represent significant advancements in stone tool technology during the period.

artefacts.name: Grinding Stones
artefacts.description: These grinding stones were vital tools used for food processing, including grinding grains and other food items. The technology behind these stones played a crucial role in the survival and development of Late Stone Age communities.

artefacts.name: Flint Knives and Blades
artefacts.description: These flint tools were essential for the survival and daily life of the Late Stone Age communities in the region. They were used for various purposes, including hunting, cutting, and crafting other tools, showcasing the advanced technology and craftsmanship of the ancient societies.

artefacts.name: Stone Arrowheads
artefacts.description: These stone arrowheads were crucial tools for the hunting and defense strategies of the Late Stone Age communities. The craftsmanship and effectiveness of these arrowheads demonstrate the ingenuity and knowledge of the ancient societies in developing sophisticated hunting equipment.

artefacts.name: Stone Hammers and Mauls
artefacts.description: These stone tools served various purposes, including woodworking, breaking bones, and processing food. The durable and versatile nature of stone hammers and mauls contributed significantly to the survival and development of the Late Stone Age communities in the region.

artefacts.name: Bone and Antler Tools
artefacts.description: These tools, crafted from animal bones and antlers, demonstrate the resourcefulness and inventiveness of the Late Stone Age communities. They were used for a variety of tasks, including crafting weapons, jewelry, and other utilitarian objects.

artefacts.name: Obsidian Tools
artefacts.description: The utilization of obsidian, a naturally occurring volcanic glass, showcases the advanced material knowledge and technological expertise of the Late Stone Age societies. Obsidian tools were highly valued for their sharpness and effectiveness in various tasks, including hunting and crafting.

artefacts.name: Mapungubwe Gold Rhino
artefacts.description: The Mapungubwe Gold Rhino is a masterpiece of African art and represents the cultural and artistic achievements of the Iron Age civilization in the region. It is believed to have symbolized power and prestige and was possibly used in ceremonial contexts.

artefacts.name: Great Zimbabwe Soapstone Birds
artefacts.description: The Great Zimbabwe Soapstone Birds are iconic artifacts from the Iron Age civilization of Great Zimbabwe. These sculptures are believed to have had ceremonial or religious significance and may have served as symbols of power or spiritual guardians.

artefacts.name: Benin Bronzes
artefacts.description: The Benin Bronzes are a collection of exquisite metal artworks created during the Iron Age in the Kingdom of Benin. These bronzes were made using the lost-wax casting technique and served various functions, including religious, royal, and decorative purposes.

artefacts.name: Ife Terracotta Heads
artefacts.description: The Ife Terracotta Heads are remarkable examples of artistic excellence from the Iron Age civilization of Ife. These sculptures represent human figures with highly detailed facial features and are believed to have had religious, political, or commemorative purposes.

artefacts.name: Lalibela Rock-Hewn Churches
artefacts.description: The Lalibela Rock-Hewn Churches are a group of remarkable architectural wonders from the Iron Age civilization of Lalibela. These churches were carved entirely from solid rock and are considered significant religious and pilgrimage sites, demonstrating the ingenuity and craftsmanship of the period.

artefacts.name: Axum Obelisks
artefacts.description: These obelisks are ancient architectural wonders and symbolize the cultural and historical significance of the Axumite civilization. The obelisks were erected as funerary monuments for royalty and high-ranking individuals, showcasing the advanced engineering and artistic skills of the Iron Age society.

artefacts.name: Sukur Cultural Landscape
artefacts.description: The landscape consists of terraces, stone structures, and historical settlements, reflecting the rich cultural heritage and agricultural practices of the Iron Age communities in the region. The site demonstrates the sophisticated knowledge and adaptation of the people to their natural environment.

artefacts.name: Iron Smelting Furnaces
artefacts.description: These furnaces represent the technological advancement of the Iron Age civilization in Meroe, where iron production played a crucial role in shaping the economy and society. The smelting process involved the extraction of iron from ore, demonstrating the metallurgical knowledge and expertise of the ancient community.

artefacts.name: Djenne-Djenno Adobe Architecture
artefacts.description: The city of Djenne-Djenno was built using sun-dried mud bricks (adobe), showcasing the sophisticated urban planning and construction techniques of the Iron Age societies. The buildings, including mosques and dwellings, demonstrate the integration of culture and architecture in the region.

artefacts.name: Tswana Stone Walls
artefacts.description: These stone walls were built for protection, indicating the complex social structures and settlement patterns of the society. The walls showcase the resourcefulness and innovation of the ancient communities in adapting to their environment.

artefacts.name: Luba Carved Wooden Stools
artefacts.description: These elaborately carved stools are not only functional furniture but also symbols of status, power, and royalty. The intricate designs on the stools represent cultural and spiritual beliefs, demonstrating the high level of artistic expression and craftsmanship of the Luba people.

artefacts.name: Nok Iron Tools
artefacts.description: The Nok civilization was known for its exceptional ironworking skills during the Iron Age, producing various tools and weapons. These iron tools represent the technological advancements and metalworking expertise of the Nok people, contributing to their economic and cultural development.

artefacts.name: Yoruba Indigo Dyeing Techniques
artefacts.description: The indigo dyeing process has been passed down through generations, producing vibrant and distinctive blue textiles used for clothing, art, and cultural ceremonies. The techniques showcase the rich cultural heritage and artistic traditions of the Yoruba society.

artefacts.name: Dogon Masks
artefacts.description: These masks hold cultural and spiritual significance, used in various rituals, ceremonies, and performances. The masks represent spirits, ancestors, and animals, reflecting the spiritual beliefs and practices of the Dogon people. They are exquisite examples of the artistic and religious expression of the Iron Age civilization.

artefacts.name: Igbo-Ukwu Bronzes
artefacts.description: These bronzes date back to the 9th century CE and are among the earliest known examples of bronze casting in sub-Saharan Africa. The intricate designs on the bronzes, including figures, animals, and objects, reveal the artistic prowess and cultural significance of the Igbo-Ukwu civilization.

artefacts.name: Bokoni Stone-Walled Terraces
artefacts.description: The stone-walled terraces were used for farming and served as defensive structures during times of conflict. The site showcases the sophisticated agricultural techniques and community organization of the Bokoni people.

artefacts.name: Kondoa Rock Art
artefacts.description: These artworks provide invaluable insights into the spiritual beliefs, daily life, and cultural practices of the Iron Age communities that once inhabited the region. The intricate and beautifully preserved paintings on the rock surfaces showcase the artistic talents and creativity of the ancient inhabitants of Kondoa.

artefacts.name: Komaland Terracotta Figures
artefacts.description: These terracotta figurines are skillfully crafted and depict human and animal forms, reflecting the rich cultural and spiritual beliefs of the region's inhabitants. The figures are a testament to the artistic excellence and cultural significance of the Komaland society.

artefacts.name: Nubian Pyramids
artefacts.description: The pyramids are architectural marvels and stand as a testament to the advanced engineering and cultural sophistication of the Nubian civilization. The site holds immense historical and archaeological significance, shedding light on the rich history of the region.

artefacts.name: Lunda Copper Currency
artefacts.description: The intricate copper-made currency pieces were produced with exceptional craftsmanship and used in trade and ceremonial transactions. The Lunda Copper Currency reflects the economic and cultural prosperity of the Lunda civilization.

artefacts.name: Timbuktu Manuscripts
artefacts.description: These manuscripts encompass a wide range of subjects, including astronomy, mathematics, literature, and religious texts, representing the intellectual and cultural achievements of the West African scholars and scribes. The manuscripts are a testament to Timbuktu's historical role as a center of learning and scholarship.

artefacts.name: Tomb of Askia
artefacts.description: The mosque is a masterpiece of West African architecture and represents the cultural and religious significance of the Songhai Empire. The Tomb of Askia stands as a testament to the rich history and architectural heritage of the region.

artefacts.name: Lalibela Crosses
artefacts.description: These intricately carved crosses hold deep spiritual significance and are associated with the historical rock-hewn churches of Lalibela, a UNESCO World Heritage site. The Lalibela Crosses are iconic symbols of Ethiopian Christianity and are considered among the most exquisite examples of African metalwork.

artefacts.name: Kilwa Pot Sherds
artefacts.description: Kilwa Kisiwani was an important trading hub and Swahili city-state known for its maritime activities and cultural exchange. The pot sherds provide valuable insights into the maritime trade, culinary practices, and artistic styles of the people who once inhabited this prosperous trading city.

artefacts.name: Great Mosque of Djenne
artefacts.description: Built during the 13th century CE, the mosque is the largest mud-brick structure in the world and a UNESCO World Heritage site. The mosque exemplifies the unique Sudano-Sahelian architectural style and holds immense cultural and religious significance as a center of worship and community gatherings in the region.

artefacts.name: Ife Bronze Heads
artefacts.description: These bronze heads showcase exceptional craftsmanship and artistic skill, capturing the facial features and expressions of prominent individuals from Ife's ancient civilization. The bronze heads are significant cultural and historical treasures, shedding light on the artistic and spiritual achievements of the Ife people.

artefacts.name: Sankore Madrasah
artefacts.description: It served as a center of Islamic education and scholarship in West Africa. The mosque is a prime example of Sudano-Sahelian architecture, characterized by its distinctive mud-brick structure and intricately decorated facade.

artefacts.name: Swahili Coral Stone Architecture
artefacts.description: The buildings are constructed using locally sourced coral stones, skillfully cut and assembled to create beautiful and durable structures. The architecture reflects the rich cultural exchange between the Swahili Coast and the Indian Ocean trade networks.

artefacts.name: Swahili Trading Beads
artefacts.description: Intricate glass beads that served as essential trade commodities and symbols of wealth and status. They provide valuable insights into the extensive trade networks and cultural connections that flourished in the East African coast.

artefacts.name: Kano Bronze Sculptures
artefacts.description: These bronze sculptures exemplify the artistic brilliance of the Kano civilization. The sculptures are a testament to the cultural, religious, and artistic achievements of the Kano.

artefacts.name: Great Enclosure Walls
artefacts.description: They served as defensive fortifications and enclosures for the city's elite. The Great Enclosure is a symbol of the advanced engineering and architectural achievements of the Zimbabwean civilisation.

artefacts.name: Gonder Royal Enclosure
artefacts.description: The enclosure served as the royal palace for Ethiopian emperors and is known for its well-preserved castles and grand architecture.

artefacts.name: Kanem-Bornu Pottery
artefacts.description: These pottery pieces showcase the advanced techniques and decorative styles employed by the Kanem-Bornu potters. The pottery artifacts provide insights into the cultural, economic, and technological aspects of the Kanem-Bornu civilisation.

artefacts.name: Lamu Fort
artefacts.description: It served as a defensive structure during the era of Arab dominance in the region. The fort's strategic location allowed it to safeguard the island from potential invaders and pirates.

artefacts.name: Benin Ivory Carvings
artefacts.description: Skilled craftsmen in Benin produced intricate ivory carvings, often depicting scenes of royalty, cultural symbolism, and spiritual beliefs. These carvings were highly valued as luxury items and were significant indicators of wealth and prestige.

artefacts.name: Aksum Obelisks
artefacts.description: These obelisks served as grand funerary stelae. The obelisks are made of single blocks of granite, and some of them are among the tallest obelisks ever erected in the ancient world.

artefacts.name: Dahomey Terracotta Figures
artefacts.description: They represent the skilled craftsmanship and artistic expression of the Dahomey people. The figures showcase a variety of subjects, including human forms, animals, and cultural symbolism.

artefacts.name: Meroitic Inscriptions
artefacts.description: These inscriptions were primarily written in the Meroitic script, an indigenous writing system. The inscriptions provide valuable insights into the political, cultural, and religious aspects of the Meroitic society.

artefacts.name: Tuareg Jewelry
artefacts.description: This jewelry is known for its unique designs and use of materials such as silver and semi-precious stones. Often reflecting the wearer's social status, cultural identity, and spiritual beliefs.

artefacts.name: Maasai Beaded Jewelry
artefacts.description: This intricate jewelry is made using glass beads of various colors and patterns, skillfully assembled into necklaces. Serving as symbols of cultural identity, social status, and ceremonial significance.

artefacts.name: Yoruba Gelede Masks
artefacts.description: The Gelede masquerade is a traditional cultural performance that honors and celebrates the power of women in Yoruba society. The masks, adorned with colorful decorations, depict various characters and symbols.

artefacts.name: Kongo Power Figures
artefacts.region: Democratic Republic of the Congo, Angola
artefacts.description: The figures, carved with remarkable attention to detail, were believed to embody spiritual forces and serve as intermediaries between humans and the spirit world. They represent the sophisticated artistic and spiritual expressions of the Kongo civilization.

artefacts.name: Himba Wooden Carvings
artefacts.description: The Himba people's artistry and craftsmanship are evident in these intricate carvings, which hold cultural, spiritual, and social significance within the Himba community.

artefacts.name: Ashanti Golden Stool
artefacts.description: The stool holds immense spiritual, cultural, and political significance, serving as the symbol of the Ashanti kingdom's unity and sovereignty.

artefacts.name: Makonde Wood Carvings
artefacts.description: They showcase the Makonde people's artistic skills and cultural expressions. These wood carvings are prized as significant works of art and valued for their cultural heritage and artistic excellence.

artefacts.name: Ndebele Beadwork
artefacts.description: Using vibrant colors and intricate patterns, the Ndebele artisans skillfully craft beadwork that includes jewelry, clothing, and various decorative items. It is a celebration of the Ndebele people's rich cultural heritage and serves as a visual expression of their identity and traditions.

artefacts.name: Kente Cloth
artefacts.description: It is traditionally handwoven by skilled artisans using vibrant yarns, creating intricate patterns and designs that convey specific meanings and messages. It represents the rich cultural heritage and artistic traditions of the Ashanti people.

artefacts.name: Zulu Shields
artefacts.description: They are made from animal hide and are often adorned with decorative elements such as geometric patterns and animal motifs.

artefacts.name: Mossi Dolls
artefacts.description: These dolls, created for both children's play and ritual purposes, hold cultural and spiritual significance within the Mossi community. They serve as an important cultural artifact and reflect the Mossi people's artistic expressions.

artefacts.name: Bambara Chiwara Headdresses
artefacts.description: They were used during agricultural rituals and ceremonies, celebrating the significance of farming in the Bambara culture. They are not only intricate artistic creations but also embody the agricultural knowledge and spiritual beliefs of the Bambara society.

artefacts.name: Yoruba Egungun Masquerade Costumes
artefacts.description: The costumes, made with vibrant fabrics and adorned with intricate designs, represent various spirits and deities, and are worn by masqueraders during ceremonial performances. Yoruba Egungun Masquerade Costumes embody the artistic excellence of the Yoruba culture.

artefacts.name: Igbo Uli Body Art
artefacts.description: Uli art involves intricate and symbolic designs painted on the body using natural pigments and dyes, denoting rites of passage, marriage, and other important life events.

artefacts.name: Tutsi Basketry
artefacts.locationName: Rwanda, Burundi, Uganda, Democratic Republic of the Congo
artefacts.description: These baskets are meticulously woven from natural materials such as grasses and raffia, resulting in exquisite designs and patterns. Tutsi Basketry serves both practical and cultural purposes, used for storage, transportation, and as decorative items.

artefacts.name: Igbo Mbari Houses
artefacts.description: These houses, characterized by their distinct design and vibrant murals served as communal spaces for art, dance, and religious ceremonies. They are living representations of Igbo cosmology, creativity, and religious practices.

artefacts.name: Chokwe Wooden Masks
artefacts.description: These masks are used in various ceremonies, rituals, and social events. Chokwe Wooden Masks are a testament to the artistic skills and cultural identity of the Chokwe community.

artefacts.name: Kuba Raffia Textiles
artefacts.description: They are woven from raffia palm fibers and are renowned for their intricate patterns and exquisite craftsmanship. The textiles showcase the Kuba people's mastery of textile arts.

artefacts.name: Lobi Bateba Sculptures
artefacts.description: Lobi Bateba Sculptures are believed to offer protection, guidance, and blessings to the community. They reflect the Lobi people's deep spiritual connections and artistic expressions, exemplifying the interplay between art, spirituality, and daily life in Lobi society.
